repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Ozone Depleting Substances
            Phase-out Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Ozone Depleting
            Substances Phase-out Project for Philippines were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory; risk to
            global environment outcome was moderate; Bank performance
            was moderately unsatisfactory; and borrower performance was
            also moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            includes: project duration. The project combined two
            operations in one over a 17-year period. While this approach
            may have had advantages from the point of view of
            bureaucratic processing, it also had disadvantages. Notably,
            closure of first phase when the investment sub-projects were
            completed would have allowed a formal valuation of the first
            phase implementation experience which could have contributed
            to second phase design. Furthermore, having been designed as
            part of an ongoing project rather than a self-standing new
            operation, second phase did not benefit from a formal World
            Bank appraisal, this might have uncovered some of the design
            weaknesses that plagued second phase implementation.
            Furthermore, due to the long duration of the project, the
            evaluation of the earlier implementation years was
            significantly constrained by staff changes in the relevant
            Government agencies and the Bank, and changes in the
            enterprises that benefitted from the Project. Monitoring
            outcomes vs. outputs. A limited number of the planned
            project outputs were achieved and contributed to the
            achievement of the Global Environment Objective (GEO) during
            second phase. The Philippines was reaching the objectives
            set for the project mainly due to factors external to the
            project, while a number of planned project outputs were
            either not being generated or poorly generated.
            Implementation progress monitoring. The project demonstrated
            that the Bank could have better assessed implementation
            progress. Voucher system design and implementation. The
            experience with the voucher scheme implementation under the
            project highlighted the need to make sure that financial and
            time costs for service shops' participation in the
            scheme are minimal, and a rigorous, adequately funded
            monitoring system is in place from the very beginning to
            ensure that no parties in the system engage in abuses, all
            eligible beneficiaries receive proper equipment and use them properly.

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Montreal Protocol Ozone
            Depleting Substances Phase Out Investment Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The closing date for Philippines,
            Montreal Protocol Ozone Depleting Substances Phase Out
            Investment Project will be extended from June 30, 2010 until
            June 30, 2011. The government requests for an extension of
            the project beyond June 30, 2010 to enable them to
            effectively ban the use of Chlorofluorocarbons (CFC) (other
            than banked supplies) in the servicing sector (small- to
            medium-scale enterprises) as well as complete the remaining
            support activities. This is consistent with the decision of
            the Executive Committee of the Multilateral Fund of the
            Montreal Protocol in its 21st meeting of parties to the
            Montreal Protocol held last November 3-8, 2009, approving
            the revised National CFC Phase out Project (NCPP) Annual
            Program which describes the action plan and the disbursement
            schedule for the remaining funds to complete the project.
            Likewise, the ISP also received fresh funds from the Fund to
            support its work on or before December 2011. However, the
            World Bank finds it sufficient to extend the project up to
            only until June 30, 2011 as the fresh funds released from
            the Fund amounts to only $158,491.00 in addition to the
            remaining project fund of US$1,865,000.

5080216.trustfund:
TF056617-SWEDISH CONTRIBUTION TO THE
            PHILIPPINE NATIONAL CFC PHAEOUT PROJECT,TF021931-OTF - PHILIPPINES ODS PHASE OUT
            INV. PROJ.

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Second Montreal Protocol
            Ozone Depleting Substances Phase Out Investment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Montreal
            Protocol Ozone Depleting Substances Phase Out Project is to
            support the Government's program to phase out Ozone
            Depleting Substances (ODS) by: 1) establishing an efficient
            mechanism for executing ODS phaseout projects through local
            institutions; and 2) implementing an initial group of cost
            effective priority subprojects.  The project includes an
            investment component and a technical assistance (TA)
            component.  The TA component includes: a) an institutional
            strengthening project to strengthen the capability of the
            Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) to
            implement the country ODS phase out program; and b)
            technical assistance to the financial agent, the Land Bank
            of the Philippines, to strengthen its capability to appraise
            and supervise ODS investment projects.  The investment
            component will support sixteen subprojects in: a) ODS
            refrigerant recycling; and b) conversion to non-ODS
            technology in solvents, refrigeration, foam blowing and
            tobacco puffing.
